body:
I agree with @theigl that you should be able to do this without adding the new API method.
For example you could use a IRequestCycleListener that uses ` Session.get().getPageManager().untouchPage(page);` whenever some condition is met, e.g. when a specific RequestCycle metadata is set (in the Ajax callback method).
Thank you, @renoth !

The changes are really small, so I am OK without ticket.

I can convert the file to Application_cs.utf8.properties, should I make another PR? Or is there a reason why you keep using encoded version of .properties?
If needed/wanted, I could convert all .properties to .utf8.properties.

But please create a ticket in JIRA for the changelog!

Created: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-7063
In what branch should I do the change? Will you cherry-pick it to other branches? 
And should I also rename all files to contain .utf8. in the filename, even if there are no encoded entities in the file, so it is future-proof?

> In what branch should I do the change?

`master`

> Will you cherry-pick it to other branches?

If requested - yes!


> And should I also rename all files to contain .utf8. in the filename, even if there are no encoded entities in the file, so it is future-proof?

Yes, please!

Hello @Taher-Ghaleb 

please revert your commit labeled `[Refactor throws Exception using assertThrows](https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/601/commits/d667bafbb8081b87fc6dc764f7fc895b066b96d7)`

It breaks the build, because:

If tests is defined as follows:
```
@Test
	void testExceptionOnMissingResourceDefaultValue() throws Exception
```

It doesn't mean it expects the `Exception` to be thrown
It only states some method **might** throw `Exception` so we should add `try-catch` OR `throws Exception` to satisfy compiler :)

Thanks @solomax for your feedback.

I must have misunderstood the actual objective of these cases. I will revert that commit shortly.

In our research, we have actually encountered test cases where developers refactor exception handling operations using the `assertThrows` assertion (e.g., instead of using `@Test(expected)`). Therefore, we wanted to understand whether such refactoring is commonly acceptable in practice by developers and whether there are certain cases where it is not preferred by submitting such pull requests, but I mistakenly chose test cases with different behavior. Thanks.

> where developers refactor exception handling operations using the assertThrows assertion (e.g., instead of using @Test(expected))

AFAIK `@Test(expected)` is **JUnit-4** way of checking exception was thrown, while `assertThrows` is **JUnit-5** way :)))

for ex. see here: https://www.baeldung.com/junit-5-migration#1-annotations
Should I change the title and description of the pull request to reflect the eventual changes performed?

> Should I change the title and description of the pull request to reflect the eventual changes performed?

Yes, please :))
Additionally JIRA issue need to be created here https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/WICKET

I can take care of both steps :)

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`. You can also ignore all major, minor, or patch releases for a dependency by adding an [`ignore` condition](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/configuration-options-for-dependency-updates#ignore) with the desired `update_types` to your config file.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.
This one produce outstanding amount of email :(
This is one time only. From now on it will be a separate PR for each new update, i.e. few PRs per week.

Depending on your configuration and choice of analysis tool, future pull requests will be annotated with code scanning analysis results. For more information about GitHub code scanning, check out [the documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/code-scanning/automatically-scanning-your-code-for-vulnerabilities-and-errors/about-code-scanning).

So thanks for the offer, but it's probably best if I create the ticket myself so I include all relevant background information.

IClusterable was introduced so that cache providers, like [Terracotta](https://www.terracotta.org/), could decide what is Wicket specific and what is generic-Serializable.
For consistency with the other Wicket classes I'd prefer to use `IClusterable` here too.

@timtebeek Could you please take a look at the CI failure here ?
Is it safe to exclude the Gradle dependencies ? Wicket is Maven based, so I think it should be OK !

Locally I made this change:
```diff
diff --git i/wicket-migration/pom.xml w/wicket-migration/pom.xml
index 38f5f33ca7..b7deefd921 100644
--- i/wicket-migration/pom.xml
+++ w/wicket-migration/pom.xml
@@ -16,6 +16,17 @@
                 <artifactId>jakarta.activation-api</artifactId>
                 <version>2.1.2</version>
             </dependency>
+            <dependency>
+                <groupId>org.openrewrite.recipe</groupId>
+                <artifactId>rewrite-migrate-java</artifactId>
+                <version>2.1.1</version>
+                <exclusions>
+                    <exclusion>
+                        <groupId>org.openrewrite</groupId>
+                        <artifactId>rewrite-gradle</artifactId>
+                    </exclusion>
+                </exclusions>
+            </dependency>
             <dependency>
                 <groupId>com.google.errorprone</groupId>
                 <artifactId>error_prone_annotations</artifactId>
```

but now it fails with:
```
[WARNING] 
Dependency convergence error for org.openrewrite.gradle.tooling:model:jar:1.3.0:runtime paths to dependency are:
+-org.apache.wicket:wicket-migration:jar:10.0.0-M2-SNAPSHOT
  +-org.openrewrite.recipe:rewrite-migrate-java:jar:2.1.1:compile
    +-org.openrewrite.recipe:rewrite-java-dependencies:jar:1.0.10:runtime
      +-org.openrewrite.gradle.tooling:model:jar:1.3.0:runtime
and
+-org.apache.wicket:wicket-migration:jar:10.0.0-M2-SNAPSHOT
  +-org.openrewrite.recipe:rewrite-migrate-java:jar:2.1.1:compile
    +-org.openrewrite.gradle.tooling:model:jar:1.3.1:runtime

[ERROR] Rule 1: org.apache.maven.plugins.enforcer.DependencyConvergence failed with message:
Failed while enforcing releasability. See above detailed error message.
```
@papegaaij Do we want to update Weld/CDI to a newer (latest?!) version for Wicket 10.x ?

I could not find any situable object to synchronize on.
The HttpSessionStore is one instance per application. Because at least org.apache.wicket.Session#exists() is called in every request,
 synchronizing on its instance would mean synchronizing all requests incoming to that application. We have about 1000 requests per second in morning /evening peaks. I think that synchronizing 1000 req/s. one by one would have serious P4M impact.
Synchronization on one single session would be the best solution. But web containers can return different HttpSession object instances per 1 single session.
I even cannot introduce some kind of a lock object and put it in the session as an attribute. Because while calling the getAttribute I could get an IllegalStateException because of invalid session.
I aknowledge that throwing an IllegalStateException as an indication of invalid session is not very nice but so is the J2EE spec.

Thanks for the explanation!
I wanted to re-open the PR but it seems you already deleted the branch.
I guess we will come up with a similar solution ...
Thanks for restoring it!

@martin-g I am afraid there is no ideal solution of this problem. It is bad by design of the specs. We can:

1. Sync on some object like the SessionStore and loose performance. Bad.
2. Log the `IllegalStateException` and continue (and hope everyone runs a container that is following the specs).
3. Figure out some snyc object related to the session itself which is not obtained via getAttribute.
4. Build a `ConcurrentHashMap` of locks, keyed by session ID strings inside the HttpSessionStore. Memory intensive and ugly.

@martin-g Weld 4.x is for JEE9, 5.x is for JEE10. I do not expect much support on 4.x, so I think we should upgrade to 5. Also, these dependencies are for tests only, so it won't make much of a difference.

Another question is if we want to target JEE9 or JEE10 with Wicket 10. I think all application servers target 10.
@DavesMan  completely agree with our considerations and I also hoped for more  "exhaustive" specs about concurrent access to Session object. :-/

Hmm; that's odd. I'd have expected those to converge, as we release such that they should all pick up the latest versions in order.

Adding a few links for context to help me debug this when I find more time:
 - https://github.com/openrewrite/rewrite-gradle-tooling-model/releases/tag/v1.3.1 (Sep 30th)
 - https://github.com/openrewrite/rewrite-java-dependencies/releases/tag/v1.0.10 (Oct 3rd, 3:26 AM)
 - https://github.com/openrewrite/rewrite-migrate-java/releases/tag/v2.1.1 (Oct 3rd, 6:13 PM)
 - https://github.com/openrewrite/rewrite-recipe-bom/releases/tag/v2.3.1 (Oct 3rd, 9:20 PM)

@kunli2 was there anything particular about the last release train that might have caused `rewrite-java-dependencies:1.0.10` to use the older `gradle.tooling:model:1.3.0`?
I'll take a new look soon!
Thank you, @DavesMan !

We've determined that we likely need another release train to flush out these dependency convergence issues, which will result in a new rewrite-recipe-bom version, and thus a new Dependabot PR. As such no action is needed here right now; we expect a new release either this week or next. We can close this issue before then, or wait for Dependabot to close the issue.

Issues:
1) it does not override `before()` and `licenseHeaders()`
2) even when 1) is fixed it does not check the sources of `wicket-core` module

**Update**: Fixed

If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`. You can also ignore all major, minor, or patch releases for a dependency by adding an [`ignore` condition](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/configuration-options-for-dependency-updates#ignore) with the desired `update_types` to your config file.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

What is the model object of `statusModel.poly(NotSubmitted.class)` if the status isn't a NotSubmitted but instance of another subclass?

> What is the model object of `statusModel.poly(NotSubmitted.class)` if the status isn't a NotSubmitted but instance of another subclass?

`null`

> `null`

Ah, should have taken a look at the code changes ;)

As a user of that API a null in that case seems surprising to me. But I'm ok with it.
To be on the safe side I'd suggest to introduce `Wicket.Event.requestSubmit(f)` function that checks for availability and uses it or falls back to the current code if not available.
